content.raw:
We could create our own meshes or use an open source model to upload into gazebo.  Artists are likely to use Blender which has some issues with the collada export and this fix works for Mixamo \(no distribution\).  
For the RMF project, we’re uploading our own models into Mixamo’s animation.

There are some open source humans here but it’s likely these animations won’t work in Gazebo:  
[https://opengameart.org/art-search-advanced?keys=character&title=&field\_art\_tags\_tid\_op=or&field\_art\_tags\_tid=&name=&field\_art\_type\_tid%5B%5D=10&sort\_by=count&sort\_order=DESC&items\_per\_page=24&Collection=](https://opengameart.org/art-search-advanced?keys=character&title=&field_art_tags_tid_op=or&field_art_tags_tid=&name=&field_art_type_tid%5B%5D=10&sort_by=count&sort_order=DESC&items_per_page=24&Collection=)
content.html:
We could create our own meshes or use an open source model to upload into gazebo. Artists are likely to use Blender which has some issues with the collada export and this fix works for Mixamo (no distribution).
For the RMF project, we’re uploading our own models into Mixamo’s animation.

There are some open source humans here but it’s likely these animations won’t work in Gazebo:
https://opengameart.org/art-search-advanced?keys=character&title=&field_art_tags_tid_op=or&field_art_tags_tid=&name=&field_art_type_tid%5B%5D=10&sort_by=count&sort_order=DESC&items_per_page=24&Collection=

* add some const accessor so that plugins can access the skeleton animations
* fix skin scaling

    * skin scaling now scale the scene node instead of the skeletons
    
* fix jerky animation at speed < 1
* fix more distorted model

this supersede pull request #3078

content.raw: I'm fine with merging this before adding the tests as long as @chapulina is happy and we create an issue to add the tests
content.html: I'm fine with merging this before adding the tests as long as @chapulina is happy and we create an issue to add the tests

content.raw: I have to agree with this, having things prefixed with “Get” also make things more readable. In qt creator for example, the class outline sorts the methods alphabetically, I can quickly see all the properties accessible by looking at the “Get\*”
content.html: I have to agree with this, having things prefixed with “Get” also make things more readable. In qt creator for example, the class outline sorts the methods alphabetically, I can quickly see all the properties accessible by looking at the “Get*”

content.raw: This is exactly the problem with removing `Get`s, though. If we need to “help” the compiler to understand our code, then that seems like a serious style problem to me. There seem to be recurring technical issues with the combination of `UpperCamelCase` functions and not allowing the `Get` prefix, and this is another data point in that recurring problem.
content.html: This is exactly the problem with removing Gets, though. If we need to “help” the compiler to understand our code, then that seems like a serious style problem to me. There seem to be recurring technical issues with the combination of UpperCamelCase functions and not allowing the Get prefix, and this is another data point in that recurring problem.

content.raw: I think we need to give the compiler a bit of help with these, maybe using the full namespace both in the header and the implementation?

content.html: Calling this Mesh() conflicts with multiple places that uses Mesh as class name.

content.raw: the plan would be to deprecate GetName in gazebo10 and just recommend that people use `Name()`
content.html: the plan would be to deprecate GetName in gazebo10 and just recommend that people use Name()

content.raw: Wouldn't it be really inconsistent if we have the const overload be called differently? We would have a `GetName()` and `Name()` method and it is hard to explain why you have to use `Name()` instead of `GetName()` if you have a const object.
content.html: Wouldn't it be really inconsistent if we have the const overload be called differently? We would have a GetName() and Name() method and it is hard to explain why you have to use Name() instead of GetName() if you have a const object.

content.raw: yeah, I misread the postfix decrement in `it2 = it1--` line
content.html: yeah, I misread the postfix decrement in it2 = it1-- line

content.raw: we can't change the name of the existing function in this pull request, since that would break API, but the new `Name() const` can be different
content.html: we can't change the name of the existing function in this pull request, since that would break API, but the new Name() const can be different

content.raw: it also doesn’t handle the case where you interpolate between the last and first frame in a looping animation
content.html: it also doesn’t handle the case where you interpolate between the last and first frame in a looping animation

Oh nice, looks like we’re safe then

But it doesn’t look like we’re handling the degenerate case where there are no keyframes at all. Handling that case is outside the scope of this PR, but maybe it would make sense to put something like

if(this->length == 0.0)
{
  /* print warning */
  return {};
}

content.raw:
hmm actually the doc for map::upper\_bound says \`Iterator pointing to the first element that is _greater_ than `key`. If no such element is found, past-the-end \(see `end()`\) iterator is returned.\`

hence if time == this->length, `end()` will be returned and dereferencing it will be an error.

edit: nvm there is another line that checks for this situation

```
  if (ignition::math::equal(time, this->length))
    return this->keyFrames.rbegin()->second;
```
content.html:
hmm actually the doc for map::upper_bound says `Iterator pointing to the first element that is greater than key. If no such element is found, past-the-end (see end()) iterator is returned.`

hence if time == this->length, end() will be returned and dereferencing it will be an error.

edit: nvm there is another line that checks for this situation

  if (ignition::math::equal(time, this->length))
    return this->keyFrames.rbegin()->second;

there is a check before this that sets time to be not more than the last frame.

  double time = _time;
  if (time > this->length)
  {
    if (_loop)
      while (time > this->length)
        time = time - this->length;
    else
      time = this->length;
  }

content.raw: It seems to me like we may need to be concerned about `it2` being the `end` iterator, in the case that `_time` is greater than the time of the maximum key frame.
content.html: It seems to me like we may need to be concerned about it2 being the end iterator, in the case that _time is greater than the time of the maximum key frame.

content.raw: @iamironcat The model doesn’t have fancy textures yet and the animation is also not continuous \(should be a small fix\).
content.html: @iamironcat The model doesn’t have fancy textures yet and the animation is also not continuous (should be a small fix).

content.raw:
For the longest time, the only animated character known* to work with Gazebo was our beloved bald man. With that in mind, any changes that look reasonable (like this one) and don't break that animation should be ok. 

However though, as we start supporting more animations, it would be ideal if we added more examples which are known to work so people can use as reference in the future. Is there a chance you can add a mesh that didn't work before all these fixes, but works now, to the media folder or `gazebo_models`? It will help us not break them in the future.


\* Known to me, and I've looked around quite a lot, but it's possible that there have been people out there using other animations successfully all along.
content.html:
For the longest time, the only animated character known* to work with Gazebo was our beloved bald man. With that in mind, any changes that look reasonable (like this one) and don't break that animation should be ok.

However though, as we start supporting more animations, it would be ideal if we added more examples which are known to work so people can use as reference in the future. Is there a chance you can add a mesh that didn't work before all these fixes, but works now, to the media folder or gazebo_models? It will help us not break them in the future.

* Known to me, and I've looked around quite a lot, but it's possible that there have been people out there using other animations successfully all along.

content.html: Can you put more of these comments in the header file? The \brief is there is pretty sparse, but this has good information here
